title-group.article-title: Relations Among Teasing, Body Satisfaction, Self-Esteem, and Depression in Treatment-Seeking Obese African American Adolescents

article-meta.aff: 1St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital, Memphis, TN, USA

author-notes.corresp: Jerlym S. Porter, 262 Danny Thomas Place, Mail Stop 740, Memphis, TN 38105, USA. Email: jerlym.porter@stjude.org

abstract.p: The objective of this study was to examine correlates of weight-based teasing, self-esteem, and depression among 119 treatment-seeking obese African American adolescents aged 11 to 18 years. Body satisfaction was examined as a potential mediator of the association between teasing and self-esteem and teasing and depression. Study participants (mean age = 13.9 years; 72% female) completed measures evaluating teasing, self-esteem, depression, and body satisfaction. Body satisfaction was measured using a multiethnic figure rating scale and a measure of overall satisfaction with appearance. The results indicated an association between teasing and decreased self-esteem and increased depression. Males exhibited higher body satisfaction than females. Body satisfaction partially mediated the association between teasing and self-esteem and teasing and depression. These data suggest that body satisfaction is relevant to well-being among obese African American adolescents seeking weight loss treatment.

body.p: Nearly 36% of adults and 17% of children and adolescents are classified as obese (Flegal, Carroll, Kit, & Ogden, 2012; Ogden, Carroll, Kit, & Flegal, 2012). African Americans are at increased risk for obesity: Among African American adults, obesity prevalence is 51% greater than among Whites (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2009), and over two decades, the prevalence of obesity among African American adolescents has increased from 13% to 24% compared with 11% to 18% for all adolescents (Ogden, Carroll, Curtin, Lamb, & Flegal, 2010; Ogden, Flegal, Carroll, & Johnson, 2002). Obesity in adolescents is of particular concern because the period of adolescence is characteristic of physiological (e.g., body composition and pubertal maturation), behavioral (e.g., diet and physical activity), and psychological (e.g., depression and body satisfaction) changes (Alberga, Sigal, Goldfield, Prud’ Homme, & Kenny, 2012). Furthermore, social networks and peer relationships are important in shaping an adolescent’s sense of identity during this time period and overweight status may negatively affect these relationships. The National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health found that overweight adolescents received fewer friendship nominations from others compared with their normal weight peers (Strauss & Pollack, 2003). Consequently, obese adolescents are at risk for psychosocial problems, such as low self-esteem and depression (French, Story, & Perry, 1995; Needham & Crosnoe, 2005; Swallen, Reither, Haas, & Meier, 2005). A recent longitudinal study found that children who were obese at baseline were more likely to report low self-esteem 4 years later compared with children of normal body weight (F. Wang, Wild, Kipp, Kuhle, & Veugelers, 2009). Obese adolescents with low self-esteem have significantly higher rates of sadness and loneliness and are more likely to engage in risky behaviors such as using tobacco or alcohol (Strauss, 2000).

A common experience for overweight and obese children and adolescents that can affect psychosocial functioning is stigmatization about weight (Puhl & Latner, 2007). Weight-related teasing is often linked with both stigmatization and poor psychosocial well-being among obese children and adolescents (Hayden-Wade et al., 2005; Stern et al., 2007; Young-Hyman, Schlundt, Herman-Wenderoth, & Bozylinski, 2003), in addition to poor health behaviors, such as overinvolvement in sedentary activities (Hayden-Wade et al., 2005). Furthermore, there is evidence that teasing persists over time. Specifically, teasing in adolescence continues as hurtful weight-related comments in young adulthood (Eisenberg, Berge, Fulkerson, & Neumark-Sztainer, 2011).

Another psychosocial factor related to obesity and weight-based teasing is body image. Body image is a person’s perception of the appearance and function of his or her body (Smolak & Levine, 2001). It is associated with both self-esteem and depression (Phares, Steinberg, & Thompson, 2004; Stice & Bearman, 2001; P. A. van den Berg, Mond, Eisenberg, Ackard, & Neumark-Sztainer, 2010). Body satisfaction is an affective component of body image, indicating how a person feels about his or her body and is related to weight-related teasing and self-esteem (Tyler, Johnston, Dalton, & Foreyt, 2009; P. A. van den Berg et al., 2010). Weight-related teasing can affect an adolescent’s body image by reinforcing body dissatisfaction; in turn, body dissatisfaction can lower self-esteem and lead to more serious consequences such as depressive symptoms and suicidal ideation (Eisenberg, Neumark-Sztainer, & Story, 2003; Vessey, Swanson, & Hagedorn, 1995).

Ethnic differences in the impact of overweight and obesity on African American youth have been explored, indicating that African American adolescents report less impairment in psychosocial functioning than other ethnic groups (Fallon et al., 2005; Modi et al., 2008). With respect to teasing, one study found that general weight-related teasing was similar across racial and ethnic groups; however, African American female adolescents were less bothered by peer teasing than their Caucasian peers (P. van den Berg, Neumark-Sztainer, Eisenberg, & Haines, 2008). Little is known about the psychosocial functioning and teasing among treatment-seeking obese African American adolescents.

There is a large body of research demonstrating ethnic differences with various aspects of body image (Demarest & Allen, 2000; S. Kumanyika, Wilson, & Guilford-Davenport, 1993). Specifically, African Americans espouse a larger ideal body size (Fitzgibbon, Blackman, & Avellone, 2000; Perry, Rosenblatt, & Wang, 2004) and are more satisfied with their bodies than European Americans (Henriques, Calhoun, & Cann, 1996; Powell & Kahn, 1994; Rucker & Cash, 1992). These differences have been found to be a function of age such that the greatest difference between body satisfaction between African American and European American women occurs during late adolescence and young adulthood and smaller differences in childhood and late adulthood (Grabe & Hyde, 2006; Wildes, Emery, & Simons, 2001). One meta-analysis found that these ethnic differences in body dissatisfaction were small and smaller than gender differences in body dissatisfaction in comparison. The authors suggest that even though African Americans may not have the same issues with body dissatisfaction, it does not mean that they are without dissatisfaction (Grabe & Hyde, 2006). Despite the large body of literature examining ethnic differences in body image, limited attention has been given to how African American adolescents differentially perceive their body image. Thus, there is a need to gain a better understanding of African American body satisfaction, and much less is known about the body satisfaction of African American adolescents seeking weight loss treatment. Understanding how body satisfaction relates to teasing, self-esteem, and depression in this age group might be an important step in developing effective interventions that improve the psychosocial well-being of African American obese adolescents.

The purpose of the current study was to understand how teasing, body satisfaction, self-esteem, and depression are interrelated in treatment-seeking obese African American adolescents (body mass index [BMI] ≥ 95th percentile). We examined the following hypotheses: (1) Perceptions of teasing will be related to self-esteem and depression such that adolescents who report higher levels of teasing will report lower self-esteem and higher levels of depression. (2) Body satisfaction will be related to teasing, self-esteem, and depression such that adolescents who report higher body satisfaction will report less teasing, higher self-esteem, and lower levels of depression. (3) Demographic variables (sex, age, BMI) will be related to teasing, self-esteem, depression, and body satisfaction. Females will report lower body satisfaction compared with males because of the greater emphasis placed on body and appearance for females than males (Demarest & Allen, 2000). Older adolescents may report less teasing because they may have more experience with learning to cope and responding to teasing more effectively than younger adolescents (Neumark-Sztainer, Story, & Faibisch, 1998). Differences in weight status may influence these variables such that adolescents with higher BMIs may be more likely to be teased, have lower self-esteem and body satisfaction, and higher levels of depression (Young-Hyman et al., 2003). (4) Body satisfaction will mediate the relationship between teasing and self-esteem and depression. Adolescents who endorse lower body satisfaction will report lower self-esteem and higher levels of depression.

Most study results from pediatric weight management programs have focused primarily on the physical aspects of weight loss (i.e., BMI, body composition, and metabolic indices; Skelton, DeMattia, & Flores, 2008; Woolford, Sallinen, Clark, & Freed, 2011) and less on psychosocial aspects (i.e., emotional functioning, coping, family environment; Berry, Savoye, Melkus, & Grey, 2007). Therefore, this study adds to the current literature by examining psychosocial characteristics of treatment-seeking adolescents. Furthermore, previous studies have explored teasing, body satisfaction, self-esteem, and depression but few have used an exclusively obese African American sample. This is noteworthy because there is evidence for differences in body satisfaction for African Americans; however, it is unclear how this might influence body satisfaction among obese African American adolescents seeking weight loss treatment. We examined these psychosocial factors in a treatment-seeking sample because obese adolescents who present for weight loss treatment have a higher number of psychological complications than the general population of obese adolescents (Puder & Munsch, 2010). Additionally, impaired psychosocial functioning, such as depression, has been associated with higher rates of weight loss treatment dropout (Zeller et al., 2004). Because African Americans have higher rates of obesity relative to other groups (Ogden et al., 2010), understanding the psychosocial functioning could elucidate ways to more effectively tailor pediatric weight management interventions and identify those at risk for premature withdrawal from programs.

sec.title: Overview of Program
sec.p: Data are from the baseline phase of a multidisciplinary weight management program for adolescents. Eligible adolescents were of ages 11 to 18 years, were ≥95th BMI percentile for their age and gender, had at least one adult in the household committed to the program, and had a primary care physician responsible for their other medical needs. The program consisted of three components: nutrition, exercise, and behavior modification. Details of the program have been presented elsewhere (Stern et al., 2006).

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Participants were 119 African American adolescents with a mean age of 13.9 years (range = 11-18, SD = 1.74). Seventy-two percent were female. Obesity was defined as a BMI greater than or equal to the age- and sex-specific 95th percentile of the 2000 CDC growth charts (Kuczmarski et al., 2002). The overall mean baseline BMI percentile for age and gender was 99.2, which is in the obese range (SD = 0.61, range = 96.6-99.9) and the mean baseline percentile was in the obese range for both males and females (M BMI percentile for males = 99.3; M BMI percentile for females = 99.2). Height ranged from 56.7 to 73.0 inches (M = 64.6, SD = 3.41). Weight ranged from 115.7 to 425.1 pounds (M = 231.5, SD = 48.0).

Participants’ parents provided information about family income and parents’ education level. Insurance status also served as a proxy for socioeconomic status; greater than one third were on Medicaid, suggesting that these families were of a lower income level. Seventy-five percent had incomes less than $50,000 and less than a third had obtained a bachelor’s degree or higher (see Table 1).

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Participants were referred to the program by school nurses, pediatricians, and self-referral. Study procedures were approved by the institutional review board. Parents provided written, informed consent and adolescents provided written assent prior to program participation. For this study, only data obtained from the adolescents are reported.

sec.title: Teasing
sec.p: Teasing was measured with the Perceptions of Teasing Scale (POTS; Thompson, Coovert, Richards, Johnson, & Cattarin, 1995), an 11-item scale with two subscales: general weight teasing (6 items; e.g., “People made jokes about you being heavy”) and competency teasing (5 items; e.g., “People laughed at you because you didn’t understand something”). For the analyses in this study, we used the general weight teasing subscale (current sample α =.87; female α = .88; male α = .87). The scale has established reliability (Thompson et al., 1995) and has been used with children and adolescents (Janicke et al., 2007; Jensen & Steele, 2010). Using a 5-point Likert-type scale, respondents indicated for each item how often they experienced teasing (1 = Never, 5 = Very often) and how upset they were by the teasing (1 = Not upset, 5 = Very upset). Items were summed for a total score and higher scores indicated more reported teasing. This measure has been used with diverse populations (Hayden-Wade et al., 2005; Young-Hyman et al., 2006).

sec.title: Body satisfaction
sec.p: We used two measures to assess body satisfaction: the Appearance Evaluation subscale of the Multidimensional Body-Self Relations Questionnaire and a multiethnic figure rating scale. The Multidimensional Body-Self Relations Questionnaire (MBSRQ; Cash, 1994) is a 69-item measure assessing overall body satisfaction and has 10 subscales. In the current study, we used one subscale, the Appearance Evaluation subscale. This seven-item subscale assesses the degree of overall satisfaction with appearance (current sample α = .81; female α = .82; male α = .73). Respondents indicate the extent to which they agree or disagree with each statement on a 5-point Likert-type scale (1 = Definitely disagree, 5 = Definitely agree). Negatively stated items were reverse-scored and items were summed for a total score. Higher scores indicated higher ratings of body satisfaction. The measure has been used with diverse populations (Miller et al., 2000; Smith, Thompson, Raczynski, & Hilner, 1999).

We also used a multiethnic figure rating scale (Pulvers et al., 2004). This figure rating scale is modeled after Stunkard, Sorensen, and Schulsinger’s (1983) widely used nine-figure scale, but the figures have hair and facial features resembling people with multiethnic backgrounds. The scale consists of pictures of males and females increasing in size from very thin to obese. Participants are instructed to select two images: one that best represents their current body image and one that conveys their ideal body image. A body discrepancy score (BDS) is calculated by subtracting the ideal body image from the current body image. Positive scores indicate a desire to be smaller and negative scores indicate a desire to be larger. The discrepancy between current and ideal figures is interpreted as an indication of level of body satisfaction (Gardner, Friedman, & Jackson, 1998). This multiethnic figure rating scale has demonstrated strong associations with other validated figural scales, BMI, and body fat percentage (Pulvers et al., 2004).

sec.title: Self-esteem
sec.p: Self-esteem was measured using the Coopersmith Self-Esteem Inventory (CSEI; Coopersmith, 1981). On this 25-item inventory, respondents indicate whether the self-descriptive item is “like me” or “unlike me” (current sample α = .83; female α = .84; male α = .82). Negatively stated items were reverse-scored and items were summed for a total score. Higher scores indicated higher levels of self-esteem. The CSEI has demonstrated adequate psychometric properties and validity studies have found that the scale is correlated with the Rosenberg Scale, the Tennessee Self-concept Scale, the Janis-Field Feelings of Inadequacy Scale, peer ratings, observer Q-sorts of self-esteem, and a self-esteem interview (Blascovich & Tomaka, 1991). The measure has been used with African American samples (Enger, Howerton, & Cobbs, 1994; Wood, Hillman, & Sawilowsky, 1995).

sec.title: Depression
sec.p: Depression was measured using the Child Depression Inventory (CDI; Kovacs, 1985; Kovacs & Beck, 1977). This measure assesses symptoms of depression during the previous 2 weeks. The 27-item scale consists of a series of statements focusing on affective, cognitive, motivational, vegetative, and psychomotor symptoms of depression and each statement is ranked by severity of symptom. The scale has established reliability and validity. For each item, there are three statements and respondents indicate the statement that best describes them (current sample α = .86; female α = .85; male α = .90). Items were summed for a total score. Higher scores indicated more reported depressive symptoms. The measure has been used with a variety of populations, including African American samples (Fitzpatrick, 1993).

sec.title: Analyses
sec.p: All analyses were conducted using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (version 18.0; IBM SPSS, Chicago, IL). Correlations examined relations among teasing, body satisfaction, self-esteem, and depression. Independent samples t tests were conducted to examine potential gender differences in scores on the measures. A Bonferonni correction was used to control the alpha level for the t-test comparisons. Based on this correction, the alpha level for all t tests was adjusted to p < .01. A series of multiple regressions based on the Baron and Kenny method of mediation (1986) were conducted to examine whether body satisfaction mediated the relationship between teasing and self-esteem and depression. In each regression analysis, perception of teasing was the independent variable, self-esteem or depression the dependent variable, and body satisfaction (MBSRQ or BDS) was the mediator.

sec.title: Correlations
sec.p: As expected, the correlations between teasing and depressive symptoms and teasing and self-esteem were significant and in the predicted direction. Teasing was also negatively correlated with body satisfaction, as measured by the MBSRQ. Body satisfaction as measured by the MBSRQ was negatively associated with depressive symptoms and positively correlated with self-esteem. Body satisfaction as measured by the BDS of the multiethnic figure rating scale indicated that larger discrepancies between the current and ideal body image was positively associated with depressive symptoms and negatively correlated with self-esteem. BMI percentile was positively associated with teasing and the BDS. The body satisfaction measures were significantly correlated. When correlations were conducted by sex, for females, there were no difference in significance and direction compared with the whole sample, except the association between teasing and BMI percentile was nonsignificant. For males, the only difference compared with correlations with the whole sample was that teasing was negatively correlated with age (r = −.36, p < .05; see Table 2).

caption.p: Intercorrelations for BMI Percentile, Teasing, Depression, Self-Esteem, and Body Image.

fn.p: Note: POTS = Perceptions of Teasing Scale; CDI = Children’s Depression Inventory; CSEI = Coopersmith Self-Esteem Inventory; BDS = Body Discrepancy Score; MBSRQ = Multidimensional Body-Self Relations Questionnaire–Appearance Evaluation Subscale.

sec.title: Bivariate Sex Differences
sec.p: T tests evaluated differences between males and females on measures of self-esteem, depression, and body satisfaction. There were no sex differences in self-esteem or depression. As expected, males had higher body satisfaction than females (males M = 21.76, SD = 5.16; females M = 18.57, SD = 6.12), t(117) = −2.65, p < .01. Females manifested greater body image discrepancy than males (females M = 2.59, SD = 1.10; males M = 1.94, SD = .83), t(117) = 3.51, p < .01.

sec.title: Body Satisfaction as a Mediator Between Teasing and Self-Esteem
sec.p: Because sex was significant in the independent t tests, we conducted analyses to test whether sex moderated the relationship between teasing and self-esteem and teasing and depression, and the results were not significant. Based on these results, we controlled for sex in the regression equations. Sex was entered in the regression equation in the first step, and the other variables were entered in the second step.

sec.title: Body discrepancy score
sec.p: Teasing was a significant predictor of self-esteem (F 2,116 = 5.64, p < .01, R2 = .09, βSE,POTS = −.29, t = −3.31, p < .01) but not the BDS from the Figure Rating Scale (F 2,116 = 5.99, p < .01, R2 = .09, βBDS,POTS = .13, t = 1.52, p > .05).

sec.title: MBSRQ
sec.p: Teasing was a significant predictor of self-esteem (F 2,116 = 5.64, p < .01, R2 = .09, βSE,POTS = −.29, t = −3.31, p < .01) and body satisfaction (F 2,116 = 7.63, p < .01, R2 = .12, βMBSRQ,POTS = −.24, t = −2.80, p < .01). Teasing and body satisfaction together accounted for a significant proportion of variance in self-esteem (F 3,115 = 13.54, p < .001, R2 = .26, f 2 = .35). When entered simultaneously, body satisfaction remained significant (βSE,MBSRQ = .44, t = 5.20, p < .001); teasing also remained significant, but the absolute value of this relation was reduced (βSE,POTS = −.19, t = −2.24, p < .05). Thus, body satisfaction as measured by MBSRQ appears to partially mediate the relation between teasing and self-esteem. Sobel’s test (1982) was conducted to examine the significance of this mediating effect and results indicated that this mediator was robust (Sobel’s z = −2.52, p < .05; see Figure 1).

caption.p: Body satisfaction as a partial mediator between teasing and self-esteem.

sec.title: Body Satisfaction as a Mediator Between Teasing and Depression
Body discrepancy score
sec.p: Teasing was a significant predictor of depression (F 2,116 = 7.29, p < .01, R2 = .11, βCDI,POTS = .33, t = 3.80, p < .001) but not the BDS from the Figure Rating Scale (BDS; F 2,116 = 5.99, p < .01, R2 = .09, βBDS,POTS = .13, t = 1.52, p > .05).

sec.title: MBSRQ
sec.p: Teasing was a significant predictor of both depression (F 2,116 = 7.29, p < .01, R2 = .11, βCDI,POTS = .33, t = 3.80, p < .001) and body satisfaction (F 2,116 = 7.63, p < .01, R2 = .12, βMBSRQ,POTS = −.24, t = −2.80, p < .01). Finally, teasing and body satisfaction together accounted for a significant portion of variance in depression (F 3,115 = 13.39, p < .001, R2 = .26, f2 = .35). When entered simultaneously, body satisfaction remained significant (βCDI,MBSRQ = −.41, t = −4.78, p < .001); teasing also remained significant, but the absolute value of this relation decreased (βCDI,POTS = .23, t = 2.81, p < .01). Thus, body satisfaction as measured by MBSRQ appears to partially mediate the relationship between teasing and depression. Again, Sobel’s test (1982) examined the significance of this mediating effect and results indicated that this mediator was robust (Sobel’s z = 2.49, p < .05; see Figure 2).

caption.p: Body satisfaction as a partial mediator between teasing and depression.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Pediatric weight management programs are designed to improve the weight status and related comorbidities of obese adolescents. To improve the effectiveness of these programs, it is important to understand the psychosocial characteristics of adolescents seeking these treatments. The current study adds to the weight management literature by examining the associations among teasing, self-esteem, and depression in a sample of African American obese adolescents in a weight management program. In addition, the potential role of body satisfaction as a mediator of the relations between teasing, self-esteem, and depression was investigated. As hypothesized, results indicated that teasing is associated with several negative outcomes within this sample, including lower self-esteem and body satisfaction and greater depressive symptoms. Additionally, body satisfaction is associated with self-esteem and depressive symptoms. As expected, males exhibited higher overall body satisfaction than females and females demonstrated a larger body image discrepancy than males. This is consistent with literature showing that females tend to have a less favorable view of their bodies than males (Huang, Norman, Zabinski, Calfas, & Patrick, 2007; Meland, Haugland, & Breidablik, 2007; Y. Wang, Liang, & Chen, 2009). We also found sex differences in the correlation between teasing and age, such that teasing was associated with younger males. We hypothesized that adolescents with higher BMIs would report more teasing and higher levels of depressive symptoms and lower self-esteem and body satisfaction. Our results partially supported this: higher BMI was associated with more reported teasing and lower body satisfaction. This may be due to the fact that our sample had a mean BMI in the 99th percentile and the narrow BMI percentile range (range = 96.6-99.9) did not allow for detection of significant differences by BMI.

Our mediation hypothesis was partially supported. Current results indicated that the relations between teasing and self-esteem and teasing and depression were partially mediated by body satisfaction as measured by the MBSRQ but not the multiethnic figure rating scale when controlling for sex. Although additional longitudinal research is needed to fully investigate this association, this suggests that teasing decreases body satisfaction, which, in turn, decreases self-esteem and increases depressive symptoms. A possible explanation for differences in results between the two body satisfaction measures is that the MBSRQ is considered more of a measure of overall appearance and body satisfaction. Perhaps overall appearance satisfaction is a stronger predictor of emotional well-being than body size discrepancy. The multiethnic figure rating scale used in this study was developed for and normed on adults, which does not take into account adolescents’ self-perception of their rapidly changing bodies. Additionally, Roberts, Cash, Feingold, and Johnson’s (2006) meta-analytic review of Black-White differences in females’ body image found that the effect sizes indicating greater body satisfaction for Black women in studies using the silhouettes, such as the figure rating scale, produce effects significantly smaller than studies using weight-related or global questionnaire approaches. Nonetheless, the results suggest that body satisfaction may account for some of the variance in the relation between teasing and depression.

The current study adds to the body of research on adolescent obesity and psychological functioning. Results provide support for relations among teasing, body satisfaction, depressive symptoms, and self-esteem in an African American adolescent obese population seeking weight loss treatment. In this sample, when sex was controlled, teasing was related to lower body satisfaction, which in turn was related to a decrease in self-esteem and an increase in depressive symptoms. Although previous research demonstrates that African Americans espouse a larger body ideal and have a more positive body image than Whites (DiGioacchino, Sargent, & Topping, 2001; Parnell et al., 1996), current findings suggest that in the extremely obese (this sample’s mean BMI percentile was over 99), lower body satisfaction is evident, regardless of ethnic background.

A limitation of this study is the inability to generalize the results to a broader sample of obese African American adolescents. The treatment-seeking adolescents in this study may have been more at risk for psychological problems than those not seeking treatment (Braet, Mervielde, & Vandereycken, 1997; Modi et al., 2008). Moreover, the study’s correlational design precludes causal interpretations, and although two of the mediation models in this study were significant, the variances accounted for were relatively small. Other variables, such as familial and peer influence might also contribute to the teasing-depression relationship (Boyington et al., 2008; Fulkerson, Strauss, Neumark-Sztainer, Story, & Boutelle, 2007). Future research using a larger, more diverse sample and incorporating a longitudinal design is needed.

In addition, this study did not take into account culturally specific factors such as perceived pubertal timing, social self-image, and racial socialization, which may affect perceptions of body satisfaction. Perceived pubertal timing, an index in which individuals see themselves as being either early or late in their pubertal development, has been associated with increased internalizing and externalizing behaviors and eating disturbance (Carter, Caldwell, Matusko, Antonucci, & Jackson, 2011; Carter, Jaccard, Silverman, & Pina, 2009; Michael & Eccles, 2003). Granberg, Simons, and Simons (2009) examined the relationship between body size and social context (the availability of comparison to other African Americans) and racial socialization (the practice of educating children about African American history, culture, and values), among adolescent African American girls over a 4-year time period. They found that living in a high-density African American neighborhood and experiencing family racial socialization served as protective factors, reducing the negative influence of being overweight (Granberg et al., 2009). Future research incorporating these cultural factors will provide a more comprehensive examination of body image and obesity among African American adolescents.

This study highlights the key role of body satisfaction in the psychosocial functioning of treatment-seeking African American adolescents, thus providing guidance in informing behavioral weight management strategies for this population. Interventions that address enhancing body satisfaction and self-esteem while providing skills to combat teasing should be tested to help reduce the risk for long-term negative psychological effects of pediatric obesity. Furthermore, improved body satisfaction and self-esteem may increase individuals’ likelihood to continue participating in pediatric obesity programs and maintain behavioral changes after completion of the program. Additionally, future research exploring the influences of adolescents’ social environment as well as media and sociocultural images is warranted to encourage healthy self-images. African American adolescents may be at higher risk for the negative consequences of pediatric obesity due to exposure to social risk factors in the physical and home environment (S. K. Kumanyika & Grier, 2006) Thus, a social ecological approach to pediatric obesity for African American adolescents that addresses the multidimensional factors of psychosocial functioning, environmental and social support, as well as the larger community and societal systems and policies is needed to reduce and prevent pediatric obesity in this population.
